children.subject: Are Shewchuk's tests extremely brutal as well? I know his curve's nice.
Shewchuk's tests are pretty comparable to other profs tests in my opinion, although emphasis might be a bit different.
Last year his midterm average was 40, final was 50, tests are not easy

161, 162 and 189 sounds good from a $$max({\text{utility})}$$ standpoint, but to be honest, you will be extremely exhausted. 

useful for industry: 

161, 162, possibly 189

from a  $$max({\text{gpa})}$$ standpoint:

189 is graded with a good curve, albeit extremely brutal in terms of the test itself.

Given my experience, 162 is the most valuable of all these classes in industry, in terms of day-to-day work as well as interview questions. I would highly recommend you take it. Plus, Kubi is a great professor.

history.content:
Which 3 of the following 4 courses would make for the most useful (from the SWE industry perspective), and preferably least exhausting, schedule for Spring 20? I also prefer nicely curved classes, but that's of course a tertiary factor.

1) CS 162 - Kubiatowicz

2) EE 16B - Arcak, Sanders

3) CS 161 - Popa, Wagner

4) CS 189 - Shewchuk

Currently leaning towards 162, 161, and 189 because I want to take 162 ASAP given how useful it is in the context of industry, and Shewchuk's 189 isn't dependent on 126/127 from what I've heard. Between 16B and 161, I'm not quite sure which is lower workload but 161 seems more useful. Plus, since 16B isn't being taught by Sahai, I'd imagine the curve is not going to be as nice either. I should note that I also self-studied 16B a while back so if there's any material from 16B that 189 will build on, I will hopefully be able to catch on quickly enough. 

Any suggestions and/or thoughts on this mix of courses appreciated. Thanks.
history.subject: Spring 20 Schedule Question
